010package imagingbook.lib.math;
011
012//import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
013//import imagingbook.lib.settings.PrintPrecision;
014
015/**
016 * Implements an efficient, closed form algorithm for calculating the real 
017 * eigenvalues (&lambda;) and eigenvectors (x) of a 2x2 matrix M of the form
018 * <pre>
019 *   | A B |
020 *   | C D | </pre>
021 * There are typically (but not in general) two pairs of real-valued 
022 * solutions 
023 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>1</sub>&rang;,
024 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>&rang;
025 * such that M&middot;x<sub>k</sub> = &lambda;<sub>k</sub>&middot;x<sub>k</sub>.
026 * <p>
027 * This implementation is inspired by Blinn, Jim: "Jim Blinn's Corner: 
028 * Notation, Notation, Notation", Morgan Kaufmann (2002) -
029 * Ch. 5 ("Consider the Lowly 2x2 Matrix").
030 * Note that Blinn uses the (common computer graphics) notation 
031 * x&middot;M = &lambda;&middot;x,
032 * while this implementation adopts the notation 
033 * M&middot;x = &lambda;&middot;x, 
034 * i.e., the matrix M is transposed (elements B/C are exchanged).
035 * </p>
036 * 
037 * @author W. Burger
038 * @version 2020-02-09
039 */
040public class Eigensolver2x2 implements RealEigensolver {
041        
042        private final boolean isReal;
043        private final double[] eVals = {Double.NaN, Double.NaN};
044        private final double[][] eVecs = new double[2][];
045        
046        /**
047         * Constructor, takes a 2x2 matrix.
048         * @param M a 2x2 matrix
049         */
050        public Eigensolver2x2(double[][] M) {
051                this(M[0][0], M[0][1], M[1][0], M[1][1]);
052        }
053        
054        /**
055         * Constructor, takes the individual elements of a 2x2 matrix:
056         * <pre>
057         *   A B
058         *   C D</pre>
059         * @param A matrix element M[0,0]
060         * @param B matrix element M[0,1]
061         * @param C matrix element M[1,0]
062         * @param D matrix element M[1,1]
063         */
064        public Eigensolver2x2(double A, double B, double C, double D) {
065                this.isReal = this.solve(A, B, C, D);
066        }
067        
068        private boolean solve(double A, double B, double C, double D) {
069                final double R = (A + D) / 2;
070                final double S = (A - D) / 2;
071                final double rho = S * S + B * C;
072                
073                if (rho < 0) {  // no real-valued eigenvalues
074                        return false;
075                }
076                
077                final double T = Math.sqrt(rho);
078                this.eVals[0] = R + T;
079                this.eVals[1] = R - T;
080                if (A - D > 0) {
081                        this.eVecs[0] = new double[] { S + T, C };
082                        this.eVecs[1] = new double[] { B, -S - T };
083                }
084                else if (A - D < 0) {
085                        this.eVecs[0] = new double[] { B, -S + T};
086                        this.eVecs[1] = new double[] { S - T, C};
087                }
088                else {          // (A - D) == 0
089                        
090                        final double aB = Math.abs(B);
091                        final double aC = Math.abs(C);
092                        final double sBC = Math.sqrt(B * C);
093                        if (aB < aC) {                                                  // |B| < |C|
094                                this.eVecs[0] = new double[] { sBC, C};
095                                this.eVecs[1] = new double[] {-sBC, C};
096                        }
097                        else if (aB > aC) {                                     // |B| > |C|
098                                this.eVecs[0] = new double[] { B,  sBC};
099                                this.eVecs[1] = new double[] { B, -sBC};
100                        }
101                        else {                                                                  // |B| == |C|
102                                this.eVecs[0] = new double[] { C, C};
103                                this.eVecs[1] = new double[] {-C, C};
104                        }
105                }
106                return true;
107        }
108        
109        /**
110         * Returns {@code true} iff all eigenvalues of the associated matrix are real.
111         * @return as described
112         */
113        @Override
114        public boolean isReal() {
115                return isReal;
116        }
117        
118        /**
119         * Returns a vector holding the two real eigenvalues. Both are
120         * {@code NaN} if the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues.
121         * Otherwise the first eigenvalue is the greater of the two.
122         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
123         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
124         * @return a 2-element array of eigenvalues
125         */
126        @Override
127        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
128                return this.eVals;
129        }
130        
131        /**
132         * Returns the kth eigenvalue (lambda_k, k = 0, 1).
133         * {@code NaN} is returned if the no real eigenvalue exists.
134         * 
135         * @param k index 0 or 1
136         * @return the kth eigenvalue
137         */
138        @Override
139        public double getEigenvalue(int k) {
140                return eVals[k];
141        }
142        
143        /**
144         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvalue(int)} instead.
145         * @return the first eigenvalue (lambda_1)
146         * @deprecated
147         */
148        public double getEigenvalue1() {
149                return this.eVals[0];
150        }
151        
152        /**
153         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvalue(int)} instead.
154         * @return the second eigenvalue (lambda_2)
155         * @deprecated
156         */
157        public double getEigenvalue2() {
158                return this.eVals[1];
159        }
160        
161        /**
162         * Returns a 2x2 array holding the two real eigenvectors.
163         * When used in the form
164         * <pre>double[][] X = getEigenvalues();</pre>
165         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} contain the 1st and 2nd eigenvector,
166         * respectively. If the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues,
167         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} are both {@code null}.
168         * Otherwise {@code X[k][0]} and {@code X[k][1]} are the x/y components
169         * of the k-th eigenvector.
170         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
171         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
172         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
173         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
174         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvector(int)} instead.
175         * @return a 2-element array of 2D eigenvectors
176         * @deprecated
177         */
178        public double[][] getEigenvectors() {
179                return this.eVecs;
180        }
181        
182        /**
183         * Returns the kth eigenvector, with k = 0 or 1.
184         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
185         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
186         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
187         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
188         * @param k index 0 or 1
189         * @return the kth eigenvector
190         */
191        @Override
192        public double[] getEigenvector(int k) {
193                return this.eVecs[k];
194        }
195        
196        @Deprecated
197        public double[] getEigenvector1() {
198                return this.eVecs[0];
199        }
200        
201        @Deprecated
202        public double[] getEigenvector2() {
203                return this.eVecs[1];
204        }
205
